text.p: PRAVDA - European Commissioner for foreign relations Hans Van den Broek said countires which did not fulfil democratic norms would not be considered for entry into an enlarged EU. The EU, and the U.S. have criticised Slovakia for allegedly failing to live up to democratic standards.
- Transport workers in Bratislava, who are striking for the third straight day, say their dispute is not politically motivated.
HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - Trading in the Slovak crown was quiet on Thursday with the crown fluctuating mildly between minus 0.4 and minus 0.6 percent from the mid-point of its mark/dollar fixing basket.
- The central bank approved a request from VUB Bank, the largest Slovak commercial bank, for permission to provide mortgage loan facilities.
NARODNA OBRODA - Postova Banka, one of the largest Slovak banks, opened a branch in Vienna.

- The vice-governor of the National Bank of Slovakia, Marian Jusko, dismissed as fanciful, suggestions by some anlaysts that the correct rate of the Slovak crown would be around five percent above the mid-point of its mark/dollar basket.
- Juska also said that anyone betting on a quick devaluation of the Slovak crown would lose money.
- Prime Minister Vladimr Meciar said he was unhappy with the manner and timing of former foreign minister Pavol Hamzik's recent resignation.
- Hospitals in Bratisalva say they are short of blood supplies because of the transport strike.
- The general director of Slovenske Elektrarne, Tibor Mikus, said Slovakia could not be self-sufficient in energy supplies without nuclear power.
- At a congress of the Ruthenian people in Budapest, representatives complained that their rights were not being sufficiently respected by the Slovak government.
SLOVENSKA REPUBLIKA - The paper say that imports of Czech beer are devastating the Slovak brewing industry.
